awd_abstract_narration: 9311398  Gregor    The muscles, joints, tendons, and bones that form the joints of  weight-bearing vertebrate limbs comprise an exquisite biological  solution to a staggering difficult mechanical problem. Not only do  these joints perform essential functions such as locomotion,  climbing and leaping, they do it with grace and economy of motion.   No artifical system comes even close to solving these problems in  an elegant, functional and esthetically pleasing way. This new NSF  award to an expert in kinesthesiology (the science of biological   motion) will allow him to study an animal model system of  multijoint control using sophisticated force transducers and high  speed cinematography. The questions he will address include (1) the  contributions of each bi-articular muscle to the generalized muscle  moment at the knee and ankle joints; and (2) the power output of  each muscle-tendon unit and their contriubtion to the total joint  power.  The results will provide data that can be used to model  general solutions to these problems and will be of interest to  robotics designers, rehabilitation specialists and sports  scientists. ***
